prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
GENERAL: We want to map the CO(3-2) line (and HCN(4-3)/HCO+(4-3)) in all 5 galaxies, centered on the nucleus and covering the whole nuclear disk and ring. Their diameter is always smaller than the FOV=18”, so a single pointing is sufficient, except for N1365 for which we request a small map of 13 pointings. For the high spatial resolution of 7-15pc, we require the extended configuration C34-7 in Band 7, with 0.12” of resolution. Given the large velocity gradients in these nuclei, and the clumpy nature of the dense gas and dust, we expect no extended emission in any given channel map, and thus do not require ACA. The spatial resolution of ~7-15pc scale is a very significant improvement with respect to what we know in galaxy nuclei, but detecting the lines is not a problem, given the high fluxes (Table 2). We will observe in dual polarization mode with 1.875 GHz bandwidth per baseband, and velocity resolution of 4MHz ~ 3.6 km/s (FDM). When this velocity resolution is too high, we will smooth the spectra to 10km/s, especially in the HCN/HCO+ lines, and to search for faint velocity wings (expected to extend to 200km/s maximum) that would be signatures of outflows. The central CO(2-1) profiles obtained with the SEST 22” beam gave signals between ~40mK to 900mK, and we can expect signals of more than 7K at high resolution in CO(3-2), given the very contrasted structure found in the HST dust images. In 30min of integration time for each galaxy, we can reach an rms of 0.7K (or 1mJy at the 0.12’’ scale). The maxima of the intensity will be comfortably detected (S/N>10), and we need to spend about 1hour per source to take into account calibrations. The weaker lines of HCN(4-3)/HCO+(4-3), probing the densest clouds, will be detected with S/N=4. Also, 1 hour will allow for a correct sampling of the UV plane.
For N613: only one pointing, with rms=1mJy We can expect a continuum of at least 10 mJy at 0.87mm, which will be detected with S/N much larger than 10.

GENERAL: We want to map the CO(3-2) line (and HCN(4-3)/HCO+(4-3)) in all 5 galaxies, centered on the nucleus and covering the whole nuclear disk and ring. When this velocity resolution is too high, we will smooth the spectra to 10km/s, especially in the HCN/HCO+ lines, and to search for faint velocity wings (expected to extend to 200km/s maximum) that would be signatures of outflows. The central CO(2-1) profiles obtained with the SEST 22” beam gave signals between ~40mK to 900mK, and we can expect signals of more than 7K at high resolution in CO(3-2), given the very contrasted structure found in the HST dust images. The weaker lines of HCN(4-3)/HCO+(4-3), probing the densest clouds, will be detected with S/N=4. Also, 1 hour will allow for a correct sampling of the UV plane.
For N1326: only one pointing, with rms=1mJy We can expect a continuum of at least 5 mJy at 0.87mm, which will be detected with S/N larger than 10.

WGENERAL: We want to map the CO(3-2) line (and HCN(4-3)/HCO+(4-3)) in all 5 galaxies, centered on the nucleus and covering the whole nuclear disk and ring. Their diameter is always smaller than the FOV=18”, so a single pointing is sufficient, except for N1365 for which we request a small map of 13 pointings. For the high spatial resolution of 7-15pc, we require the extended configuration C34-7 in Band 7, with 0.12” of resolution. Given the large velocity gradients in these nuclei, and the clumpy nature of the dense gas and dust, we expect no extended emission in any given channel map, and thus do not require ACA. The spatial resolution of ~7-15pc scale is a very significant improvement with respect to what we know in galaxy nuclei, but detecting the lines is not a problem, given the high fluxes (Table 2). We will observe in dual polarization mode with 1.875 GHz bandwidth per baseband, and velocity resolution of 4MHz ~ 3.6 km/s (FDM). When this velocity resolution is too high, we will smooth the spectra to 10km/s, especially in the HCN/HCO+ lines, and to search for faint velocity wings (expected to extend to 200km/s maximum) that would be signatures of outflows. The central CO(2-1) profiles obtained with the SEST 22” beam gave signals between ~40mK to 900mK, and we can expect signals of more than 7K at high resolution in CO(3-2), given the very contrasted structure found in the HST dust images. In 30min of integration time for each galaxy, we can reach an rms of 0.7K (or 1mJy at the 0.12’’ scale). The maxima of the intensity will be comfortably detected (S/N>10), and we need to spend about 1hour per source to take into account calibrations. The weaker lines of HCN(4-3)/HCO+(4-3), probing the densest clouds, will be detected with S/N=4. Also, 1 hour will allow for a correct sampling of the UV plane.
For N1365: a mosaic of 13 pointing, with rms=3mJy We can expect a continuum of at least 50 mJy at 0.87mm, which will be detected with S/N much larger than 10.

GENERAL: We want to map the CO(3-2) line (and HCN(4-3)/HCO+(4-3)) in all 5 galaxies, centered on the nucleus and covering the whole nuclear disk and ring. Their diameter is always smaller than the FOV=18”, so a single pointing is sufficient, except for N1365 for which we request a small map of 13 pointings. For the high spatial resolution of 7-15pc, we require the extended configuration C34-7 in Band 7, with 0.12” of resolution. Given the large velocity gradients in these nuclei, and the clumpy nature of the dense gas and dust, we expect no extended emission in any given channel map, and thus do not require ACA. The spatial resolution of ~7-15pc scale is a very significant improvement with respect to what we know in galaxy nuclei, but detecting the lines is not a problem, given the high fluxes (Table 2). We will observe in dual polarization mode with 1.875 GHz bandwidth per baseband, and velocity resolution of 4MHz ~ 3.6 km/s (FDM). When this velocity resolution is too high, we will smooth the spectra to 10km/s, especially in the HCN/HCO+ lines, and to search for faint velocity wings (expected to extend to 200km/s maximum) that would be signatures of outflows. The central CO(2-1) profiles obtained with the SEST 22” beam gave signals between ~40mK to 900mK, and we can expect signals of more than 7K at high resolution in CO(3-2), given the very contrasted structure found in the HST dust images. For N1672: only one pointing, with rms=2mJy We can expect a continuum of at least 20 mJy at 0.87mm, which will be detected with S/N much larger than 10.

GENERAL: We want to map the CO(3-2) line (and HCN(4-3)/HCO+(4-3)) in all 5 galaxies, centered on the nucleus and covering the whole nuclear disk and ring. Their diameter is always smaller than the FOV=18”, so a single pointing is sufficient, except for N1365 for which we request a small map of 13 pointings. For the high spatial resolution of 7-15pc, we require the extended configuration C34-7 in Band 7, with 0.12” of resolution. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to map the morphology and kinematics of the cold dense gas in five nearby Sy/LINER nuclei at the unprecedented spatial resolution of 0.12"=7-15 pc. Up to now, our NUclei of GAlaxies (NUGA) study of molecular gas in ~20 AGN circumnuclear regions with IRAM has shown that nested, kinematically decoupled bars are able to feed the nuclei; however gas inflow is seen only in 1/3rd (7) of the cases. It is possible that different time-scales and episodic fueling account for this low rate, or that AGN and supernova (SN) feedback halt the feeding. In ALMA cycle 0, we observed the circumnuclear regions of 3 galaxies, and discovered both fueling and outflows in 2 of them, NGC1433 and NGC1068. With respect to our previous results on NUGA, with ALMA we will improve our resolution by a factor of 10 and sensitivity by a factor of 4. We will probe the multitude of potential 10pc-scale fueling mechanisms (i.e. cascade of instabilities, bending and warping, dynamical friction, turbulent viscosity) and the feedback processes driven by star formation and/or the AGN, for a galaxy sample that spans a factor of 100 in AGN power and a factor of 10 in star-formation level.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2011.0.00208.S, Feeding and Feedback in two nearby Seyfert galaxies, PI: F. Combes

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Observatorio de Madrid, Observatorio Astronómico Nacional
Institute of Radioastronomy of Bologna, INAF
IRAM Grenoble, Institute of Millimetric Radioastronomy (IRAM)
Institute of Physics I, Cologne, University of
Dept of Physics & Astronomy, Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey
IRAM Grenoble, Institute of Millimetric Radioastronomy (IRAM)
